guide.title: Gentoo Managers' Meeting Summary
guide.subtitle: 26 Jan. 2004
guide.author: Grant Goodyear
guide.abstract:
This meeting began at 1900 UTC, and the guest chair was Grant Goodyear. The principal agenda item was the Gentoo Server effort. The raw log is available
here.

body.p: Kurt Lieber announced a plan to develop an enterprise-friendly version of Gentoo. The basic idea is that Gentoo Enterprise would be extremely stable, with quarterly sets of release ebuilds guaranteed to persist for at least a year. Discussion mainly focussed on whether there should be a separate server portage tree, or whether a server keyword would suffice as an indication of which ebuilds should be "cut" to form a new release. Kurt Lieber will be releasing a GLEP to further develop these ideas.

Two developer issues were raised once the floor was opened. The first was the idea of "server metapackages", proposed by iggy. Just as KDE and GNOME have metapackages, perhaps there should also be special server metapackages so that one could, for example, "emerge vmail" to create an already-configured virtual mail system. This notion seemed to have some traction, but more work is clearly needed.

Next up was additional discussion about the separate tree for Gentoo Server. Ideas tossed around included using webrsync to get around paranoid corporate firewalls, perhaps incorporating xdelta, and a kickstart-like installation tool for Gentoo.

Weeve made (yet another) impassioned plea for devs to stop breaking packages on architectures not their own. The 2.0.50_pre series repoman now reports how changes will affect all architectures, so there really is no excuse for devs to be breaking the non-x86 trees anymore.
Finally, spyderous noted that the Gentoo Installer subproject is now underway. People who are interested should visit #gentoo-installer.
